title: Who's afraid of Elizabeth Warren?
text:
Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren's policies are bad news for bankers AP

And Warren has also vowed to repeal the Trump administration's $US1.5 trillion tax cut package, of which US banks were one of the biggest beneficiaries.

In addition to her specific policy measures, bankers have a further reason to be dismayed at Warren's standing in the polls (some polls suggest she is the front-runner, while others have former vice-president Joe Biden in the top spot).

That's because her political popularity is an unmistakeable indication of a widespread antipathy in the community towards the financial sector in general, but particularly towards the banks.

This general hostility towards the banks is not only evident in the United States. A similar aversion towards the privileged financial elite in the City of London helped fuel the Brexit revolt.

And, of course, antagonism towards the banks was evident in Australia even before the Hayne royal commission shone a spotlight on the greed and cupidity in the financial sector.

After all, the banks were the biggest individual losers from the 2017 federal budget, which stung them with a new $6.2 billion bank levy.

Since June, the Morrison government's frustration with the big banks has intensified, after they failed to pass on official rate cuts in full to their existing home loan customers.

Advertisement

So scorching is the political fury that Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has now directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to take a close look at home loan pricing, and the obstacles that prevent customers from switching banks.

Of course, the country's more astute bankers are well aware of the extent to which community and political sentiment towards their industry has soured.

They know that the only way for them to survive is to keep their head down and focus on managing their massive organisations, while trying to avoid inflaming public opinion even further.

It's against this volatile and incendiary backdrop that the banking regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority has unveiled its new pay regime, according to which only 50 per cent of a senior banker's bonus can reflect financial performance.

Even though the new remuneration rules have been widely panned, APRA boss Wayne Byres has responded by calling on critics to come up with a better suggestion "that isn't just the status quo, because outcomes from the status quo have been found unacceptable''.

But although senior bankers have been stunned by Byres' stance - which suggests that the banking regulator feels it is under such strong pressure to make changes to bankers' pay arrangements that it is prepared to push ahead with a deeply flawed policy rather than leave things as they are - they daren't risk any public criticism.

This leaves top bankers in the absurd situation where they have little choice but to adopt APRA's faulty remuneration rules, and to apply them in as sensible a fashion as possible.

Their only consolation is that although APRA's plan for rejigging bankers' bonuses will ultimately come unstuck, at least the changes Byres is proposing fall a long way short of Elizabeth Warren's policies.
description: The political momentum of Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren is symptomatic of the global backlash against bankers.
